Hello Everyone,

This afternoon PIAA announced a two week pause in required activities for fall sports.

With that in mind we are also going to pause the required timeline for marching band and CANCEL rehearsals for August 10-14, 2020.

At this time I am hoping to resume optional rehearsals on August 17-21 from 3:30-5:30. I will send confirmation for those rehearsals next week.

I will have music and part assignments emailed by Monday Morning. It will include percussion assignments.

If you need an instrument or other equipment from the school, notify me immediately and I will make sure it is put in the main office on Monday afternoon when I am at the high school. (If your instrument is in a locker please let me know which one it is)

Please look at the music and work through it to the best of your ability prior to our rehearsals. This new timeline will be challenging but doable!

Remember that writing in counts and note names is completely acceptable! Do what you need to be successful!

I will be in touch!

Thank you for your patience as we navigate these uncertain times!

Regards,
Darris

On most non-pandemic years at Penns Valley, the athletic coaches take the time to give a review of their seasons and honor their seniors at our end of the year senior awards ceremony. This year, however, we were unable to have such a ceremony.

Thank you to the coaches who took time to create videos. All coaches had the opportunity to record videos and submit highlights, which makes this a rather lengthy video... like an hour and forty minutes long! The video follows the seasons, so the fall sports are first in line, followed by the winter sports, and the spring sports.

This video is dedicated to our senior athletes and especially to our senior spring athletes who were robbed of their final spring season. And yes, our swimmers who were about to get in the pool at Bucknell for warmups when they were unceremoniously told to go home due to the coronavirus shut down by the PIAA.

Thank you to everyone who has helped make Penns Valley Athletics a great part of our school and our community.

Dear Parents,

At 10:30 a.m. this morning, Secretary of Education, Pedro Rivera announced that all K-12 Schools, Higher Education Institutions, Pre-Schools, and Pre-K Counts Programs will remain closed through the end of the 2019-2020 Academic Year. We are in the process of developing plans to move from review and enrichment to planned instruction. Planned instruction is formal teaching and learning similar to that which occurs in a classroom setting. Within this process, teachers use planned courses of instruction of new concepts/skills aligned to grade-level standards. This option can vary in forms to include online/digital and non-digital learning opportunities. We will be working in collaboration with our teachers to establish the plan. Please expect to see additional information early next week.

Kindly,

Brian K. Griffith, Superintendent

Here's some good news to share to brighten your day!

Penns Valley Area School District’s Music Education Program Receives National Recognition

Penns Valley Area School District has been honored with the Best Communities for Music Education designation from The NAMM Foundation for its outstanding commitment to music education.

This award recognizes that Penns Valley Area School Disrict is leading the way with learning opportunities as outlined in the Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA). The legislation guides implementation in the states and replaces the No Child Left Behind Act (NCLB) which was often criticized for an overemphasis on testing-while leaving behind subjects such as music. ESSA recommends music and the arts as important elements of a well-rounded education for all children.

Darris DeRemer, Penns Valley Band Director states, “Music in our schools is an essential part of creating well-rounded students who will become well-rounded adults. We aren’t just teaching music skills, we are teaching life skills.”

Congratulations to our staff and our students!

Staff has also been working tirelessly to safely accumulate and package your students' belongings and educational materials.

Our teachers have done a phenomenal job preparing supplemental learning materials for their students and giving everyone the opportunity to continue their education, even if we can't have official remote school days or graded assignments.

Know that behind the scenes there is a lot of activity trying to adjust to this quickly changing landscape. We will continue to monitor the regulations put in place and build the best possible environment for continued learning as we can. We thank you for your support and patience as we head deeper into these uncharted waters.

We wish you and your family health and safety and look forward to the time when we can all reconnect safely in person.

post_text: Students in Mrs. Harper’s Geometry class explored the concept of geometric proportionality. The essential question in this task is “How do we use math to find the height of things that are difficult to measure?” What students were doing was working within a triangle created by the flashlight and the city, and inserting blockers to serve as scaled down (dilated) versions of the same triangle. The key was to find the right place for each blocker given its size. Hopefully, they found that patterns emerged between the size of the blocker and the distance from the light: proportionality. This will be explored in greater depth throughout the unit.

When asked if she wanted to share anything extra, Regina said “I am so excited to be starting my career and living in the Penns Valley community. Even though I have been here for less than a year, it already feels like home!”

We couldn't agree more! #WelcometotheValley Regina Beers

#WelcometotheValley Joanna Stoltz

We would like to welcome one of our new PVHS English teachers, Joanna! She has been teaching for five years, and joins the PVASD team this year teaching English 10. Coming from Martinsburg, PA, Joanna decided to become a teacher because she wanted to share her love of English. She also enjoys building relationships with students, with the goal of positively influencing their lives and helping them work to reach their full potential. Joanna hopes to play a small part in helping students to become contributing members of society.

When asked what her favorite English topic was to teach, she chose the novel The Outsiders by S.E.Hinton. Her favorite thing about Penns Valley so far is getting to know her coworkers and students.

Outside of school, Joanna enjoys traveling to national parks, hiking, kayaking, reading, baking and trying new restaurants. Her favorite quote comes from Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.- “The time is always right to do what is right.”

PV is happy to say #WelcometotheValley, Joanna!

100 Days of School = 100 Days of US!

Students in Mrs. Feltenberger's 4th grade classroom generated their own ideas for celebrating the 100th Day of School. When several activities were generated, the compromise was to do a little bit of everything in what has been dubbed "100 Days of US!"

It's 1961, and ordinary teenager is drafted by the CIA to become a super-secret secret agent. The mission? Infiltrate an American high school to locate a Russian spy about to send classified space program information to the USSR. But it's not easy being undercover, especially when your spy family consists of a femme fatale "mom," a 40-year-old "younger brother," and the most dashingly narcissistic "dad" ever. Add that to obnoxious fellow students, a blatantly sexist curriculum, and the horror that is prom, and you've got a mission that might be impossible.

Penns Valley graduate, Malarie Yoder, created the banner for this play.

post_text: The Penns Valley High School will be holding a Parent Informational Session on Tuesday, December 17 at 6:00 PM regarding a 1 week Research Expedition Opportunity for students in grades 9 -12 through Operation Wallacea. Operation Wallacea (Opwall) is an organization that runs a series of biological and conservation management research programmes that operate in remote locations across the world. These expeditions are designed with specific wildlife conservation aims in mind - from identifying areas needing protection, through to implementing and assessing conservation management programs. Students who participate in this 1 week expedition will head to the Bay Islands in June 2021. They will be working alongside scientists and exploring coral reefs. For more information please contact Jessica Martin at jlmartin@pennsvalley.org or visit www.opwall.com

Congratulations to Penns Valley’s Academic Decathlon team for their second place finish at the fall scrimmage in Carlisle on November 14th.

Senior Ben Hawkins was the overall champion and top scorer in the honors division, medaling in all four subjects tested. In third place overall, winning three medals, was junior Colton Sands. Other medalists in the honors division were sophomore Jack O’Donald, junior Maria Lovallo, and junior Max Feidler.

In the scholastic division, junior Raines Whitehill finished in second place overall with two medals. Junior Harrison Reish ended up in fifth place with one medal. Junior Owen Zehr medaled twice.

In the varsity division, junior Owen Korman celebrated his Academic Decathlon debut with two medals.

The super quiz relay team of Owen Korman, Amanda Grove, Andrew Ruoff, Jules Black, Caroline Powell, Raines Whitehill, Ben Hawkins, Colton Sands, and Maddie McCool came in first place in the collaborative event.

Coaches Zatek and Farrant were proud of the team. Our next event is the winter scrimmage at Montoursville in January.

Approximately 20-25 Teams from across the northeast, from New Jersey to Ohio will travel to Penns Valley to compete in our second annual combative robotics double elimination tournament. The tournament is being brought to the Valley through the collaboration of Penns Valley Technology Student Association, The PVRAMbotics club, The Bloomsburg High School Robotics Club and the National Robotics League. The arena was built by Bloomsburg High School through a grant made possible by the Alcoa Foundation. Team check in starts at 7:30am and safety checks to start at 8:00. Bot smashing will begin at 9 AM and go until 4 PM. Come on out and see the mayhem and engineering marvels of combative robotics.

Speed dating in high school... it's not the traditional speed dating. In this speed-dating scenario, students researched prominent industrial reformers from the Industrial Revolution era and applied a speed-dating format to see who would be most likely to fall in love... well maybe fall in love with each other's philosophies on industrial reform. As for romance... not so much.

With socialists, capitalists, communists, and public servants, the choices are out there. Whether you are Thomas Mathius or Karl Marx, your perfect industrial match could be one speed -dating interview away.

This activity also builds social skills, like how to engage in conversation and non-verbal communication. The transferable skills that are reinforced go beyond trying to find Jane Adams's best industrial match. Thank you, Mrs. Troxell.

Skylar Fleshman made an impressive presentation at Keystone State Literacy Conference in Hershey in October. As a part of Lori Sullivan and Jill Geesey's unveiling of their K-9 Partnership, Skylar brought a keen insight into the students' views of the program which sometimes can get overlooked.

The K-9 Reading Partnership is an innovated program designed to promote literacy and writing skills at the kindergarten and ninth grade levels while developing a partnership between high school students and the elementary students in our community. This project is not only rewarding for all students involved, promoting writing and literacy skills, but also this program helps them practice, social skills, teaches tolerance, and builds community among grade levels.

Congratulations to Mrs. Geesey, Mrs. Sullivan, and Skylar for making us Penns Valley proud!

Students in Andy Landis's class are learning about engineering and the engineering design process. Students identified a problem and then were asked to research, build, and test a solution to the problem based on criteria and constraints given.

The problem chosen was to help students from leaning back in their chairs. This is not only a safety issue but also is destructive to them over time. They created an initial prototype and then were allowed to revise their solutions based on newly identified problems from the first. Pictured are some of the solutions.
